sourceDesc.ab: Translation of 淮南子 into English.

p.seg: 綣領 (quǎn lǐng): To roll up one's sleeves, indicating a readiness to work or fight.
襃衣博帶 (bāo yī bó dài): Elaborate clothes and wide belts, often worn by officials or the wealthy.

句襟委章甫 (gōu jīn wěi zhāng fǔ): Curved collars and trailing hats, also associated with formal attire. [The first sentence sets the scene in ancient times, describing rulers who were not focused on outward appearances but on virtuous governance. Their leadership led to a time of peace and prosperity, where nature thrived and people lived in harmony. The final question challenges the idea that elaborate clothing and accessories are necessary for effective leadership, emphasizing the importance of inner virtue over outward displays of power.]
復穴 (fù xué): Caves or burrows.
蟁䖟 (yì yǎo): Insects, particularly mosquitoes and gnats.
上棟下宇 (shàng dòng xià yǔ): A phrase describing the basic structure of a house, with a roof above and walls below.
伯余 (bó yú): A legendary figure credited with the invention of clothing.
緂麻索縷 (guàn má suǒ lǚ): To twist hemp fibers and thread them.
機杼 (jī zhù): Looms and spinning wheels. 勝複 (shèng fù): A type of loom that improved the efficiency of weaving.

[The first paragraph describes the harsh living conditions of ancient people and how the sages' invention of houses improved their lives. The second paragraph discusses the evolution of clothing production from the rudimentary methods of Bo Yu to the more advanced tools of later generations. These advancements highlight the continuous improvement of human living standards through innovation and technological progress.]
剡耜 (yǎn sì): Sharpened sticks used for plowing.
摩蜃 (mó shèn): To weed by hand.
抱甀 (bào fǒu): To carry water in jars.
耒耜耰鋤 (lěi sì yōu chú): Plows and hoes.
斧柯 (fǔ kē): Axes.
桔皋 (jié gāo): Pulleys.
窬木方板 (yú mù fāng bǎn): Hollowed-out logs and planks used for making boats.
負扆 (fù yǐ): To lean on a screen, a gesture of authority.
北面委質 (běi miàn wěi zhì): To face north and pledge loyalty, a gesture of submission.
屬籍致政 (zhǔ jí zhì zhèng): To return the throne and power.
中權 (zhòng quán): To achieve the right balance.
呂氏 (Lǚ shì): The ruling family of Qi before the coup. 陳氏 (Chén shì): The family that took over Qi after the coup.
陳成常 (Chén Chéng Cháng)
私門成黨 (sī mén chéng dǎng): To form cliques or factions within private circles.
攝威擅勢 (shè wēi shàn shì): To seize power and authority.
樓翟 (Lóu Dí): A general in the state of Wei. 吳起 (Wú Qǐ): A famous military strategist and general in ancient China.
淖齒 (Nào Chǐ): A minister in the state of Qi. 東廟 (Dōng Miào): The Eastern Temple, a location in the state of Qi.
呂望 (Lǚ Wàng): Also known as Jiang Ziya, a key advisor to King Wen and King Wu of Zhou. 召公奭 (Shào Gōng Shì): The Duke of Zhou, a respected statesman and regent of the Zhou dynasty.
